caption_original:
Monday Motivation!

Dennis Cadieux, Commanding Officer at the Rescue Station in Goderich, ON has 28 years of service with the Coast Guard. Dennis began his career as a cook aboard the CCGS Griffon. Throughout his career, he has worked seasonally as an Assistant Rescue Coordinator, Deckhand, Leading Seaman and ashore as a Regional Operations Officer. After obtaining certification, Dennis Cadieux worked as a Commanding Officer aboard CCGS Vakta and was a Commanding Officer at the Rescue Stations in Tobermory, ON and Amherstburg, ON.
caption_cleaned: Monday Motivation! Dennis Cadieux, Commanding Officer at the Rescue Station in Goderich, ON has years of service with the Coast Guard. Dennis began his career as a cook aboard the CCGS Griffon. Throughout his career, he has worked seasonally as an Assistant Rescue Coordinator, Deckhand, Leading Seaman and ashore as a Regional Operations Officer. After obtaining certification, Dennis Cadieux worked as a Commanding Officer aboard CCGS Vakta and was a Commanding Officer at the Rescue Stations in Tobermory, ON and Amherstburg, ON.

caption_original:
The Canadian Coast Guard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian Pacific Railway paid homage to a true Canadian hero with the unveiling of a commemorative plaque aboard the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Private Robertson V.C. in Burlington Ontario December 10 2017.

Private James Peter Robertson was awarded posthumously the Victoria Cross for his extraordinary valour and devotion to duty while facing a hostile force in one of the most significant battles in World War I, at Passchendaele Belgium.

CP commissioned the plaque at the request of CP engineer Darrel Sundholm of Calgary Alberta. “After his family moved from Springhill Nova Scotia to Medicine Hat Alberta, James Peter Robertson joined the Canadian Pacific Railway, working his way up to locomotive engineer. He earned his nickname “Singing Pete” for his cheerful singing and whistling, whether in the cab or at the roundhouse,” said Sundholm. “The bravery that earned him the Victoria Cross made him a legend among locomotive engineers the world over.”

Steve Pauley, Commanding Officer of the Canadian Coast Guard ship named in Robertson's honour stated at the ceremony “In this, the 100th year anniversary of his death, it is our honour to share the story of Private Robertson’s service to our country and remember his ultimate sacrifice with dignity and respect.” Pauley added “This plaque will educate all who step aboard this ship for many years to come.”
caption_cleaned: The Canadian Coast Guard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian Pacific Railway paid homage to a true Canadian hero with the unveiling of a commemorative plaque aboard the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Private Robertson V.C. in Burlington Ontario December . Private James Peter Robertson was awarded posthumously the Victoria Cross for his extraordinary valour and devotion to duty while facing a hostile force in one of the most significant battles in World War I, at Passchendaele Belgium. CP commissioned the plaque at the request of CP engineer Darrel Sundholm of Calgary Alberta. “After his family moved from Springhill Nova Scotia to Medicine Hat Alberta, James Peter Robertson joined the Canadian Pacific Railway, working his way up to locomotive engineer. He earned his nickname “Singing Pete” for his cheerful singing and whistling, whether in the cab or at the roundhouse,” said Sundholm. “The bravery that earned him the Victoria Cross made him a legend among locomotive engineers the world over.” Steve Pauley, Commanding Officer of the Canadian Coast Guard ship named in Robertson's honour stated at the ceremony “In this, the th year anniversary of his death, it is our honour to share the story of Private Robertson’s service to our country and remember his ultimate sacrifice with dignity and respect.” Pauley added “This plaque will educate all who step aboard this ship for many years to come.”

caption_original:
For the TWELFTH day of our 12 day holiday countdown ☃️… TWELVE Marine Communications and Traffic Services (MCTS) Stations!

Our MCTS centres provide distress and safety call monitoring and coordinate responses; broadcast maritime safety information (weather and navigational warnings); screen vessels entering Canadian waters; deliver information and advice to regulate marine traffic movement; and take appropriate action to ensure the safe and efficient movement of vessels in Canadian waters! http://ow.ly/HcMU30hnAXY

caption_original:
Seaspan’s Vancouver Shipyard has officially launched our first Offshore Fisheries Science Vessel under the National Shipping Strategy.  This vessel is the first of a series of new ships, marking tangible progress towards the renewal of our fleet, and of the success of the National Shipbuilding Strategy. 

The future CCGS Sir John Franklin will be a welcomed addition to our fleet! A ceremony was held on December 8th in North Vancouver to mark this historic milestone.

The future CCGS Sir John Franklin will be a welcomed addition to our fleet! A ceremony was held on December th in North Vancouver to mark this historic milestone.

caption_original:
Last month we participated in “Exercise Salish Sea,” which was the largest major incident exercise in Canadian Coast Guard history! The two-day major maritime incident training exercise took place east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia. Day two focused on practicing environmental response skills, processes and procedures, with partners. http://ow.ly/5w7I30h3O3n

Canadian Armed Forces, Transport and Infrastructure in Canada, U.S. Coast Guard

caption_original:
The Canadian Coast Guard is proud to serve mariners who travel the inland and coastal waterways of our nation.  More than 1,700 dedicated employees work in our vast Central and Arctic Region.   From operations that save lives at sea to supporting our nation's economy through safe and efficient marine transportation, we provide a multitude of essential marine services on the Great Lakes, the St. Lawrence River and Canadian Arctic waterways.

Would you like to join us on our journey? We are hiring and creating an inventory for many seagoing positions in the Central and Arctic Region. Interested? Please visit:

http://www.ccg-gcc.gc.ca/College-and-Careers/Job-openings

caption_original:
For the SIXTH day of our 12 day holiday countdown ☃️… here are SIX Coast Guard employees who have served with the Canadian Armed Forces.

Rick Fougère, Incident Command Syst. Officer, retired from the Canadian Forces after 25 years of service and transferred to the Coast Guard.

Evan Boettger, Project Director, enrolled in the Canadian Forces as a Reservist in 1976 and served until his retirement from the Royal Canadian Navy in 2015.

Rob Justice joined the Coast Guard in 2013 following a lengthy career in the Royal Canadian Navy. He is now Manager, Office of Incident Management in Ottawa.

Eric Arsenault retired from the Canadian Forces after 20 years of service and is now a National Project Manager with us.

Lieutenant-Commander Sheyla Dussault, Manager of Search and rescue, joined the Naval Reserve in 1993 and she is still serving today.
caption_cleaned: For the SIXTH day of our day holiday countdown ️… here are SIX Coast Guard employees who have served with the Canadian Armed Forces. Rick Fougère, Incident Command Syst. Officer, retired from the Canadian Forces after years of service and transferred to the Coast Guard. Evan Boettger, Project Director, enrolled in the Canadian Forces as a Reservist in and served until his retirement from the Royal Canadian Navy in . Rob Justice joined the Coast Guard in following a lengthy career in the Royal Canadian Navy. He is now Manager, Office of Incident Management in Ottawa. Eric Arsenault retired from the Canadian Forces after years of service and is now a National Project Manager with us. Lieutenant-Commander Sheyla Dussault, Manager of Search and rescue, joined the Naval Reserve in and she is still serving today.

caption_original: ᐃᖃᓗᒻᒥᐅᓄᑦ! ᐃᑲᔪᕈᒪᒐᔭᖅᑭᑦ ᐅᒥᐊᖅᑐᖅᑐᓂᒃ ᐱᔪᖃᑳᓪᓚᑦᑐᓂᒃ ᐊᑦᑕᓇᖅᑐᒃᑯᑦ ᐊᒻᒪᓗ ᐊᐳᖅᓯᑦᑕᐃᓕᒪᑎᑦᑎᓂᕐᒥᒃ ᐅᒥᐊᕐᓂᒃ? ᐊᑎᓕᐅᖁᕙᑦᓯ ᑕᕆᐅᕐᔪᐊᓕᕆᔨᒃᑯᑦ ᑲᒪᔨᒃᓴᓕᕆᔨᖏᓐᓄᑦ ᖃᐅᔨᒃᑲᐃᓂᕐᒧᑦ ᐃᖏᕐᕋᔪᓕᕆᓂᕐᒧᓪᓗ (MCTS-ᖑᓂᕋᖅᑕᐅᔪᖅ) ᐆᑦᑐᕋᖅᑎᑕᐅᖃᑕᐅᓂᐊᕋᕕᑦ ᐃᖃᓗᓐᓂ ᓈᑦᑎᖑᔭᒥ ᑎᓯᐱᕆ 18, Services Canada-ᒃᑯᓐᓂ 933 ᐊᖅᑯᑎᖓ ᒥᕝᕕᐅᓂᕋᖅᑕᐅᔪᖅ, 1-ᒨᖅᑲᑦ. ᐆᑦᑐᖅᑕᐅᓂᐊᖅᑐᑦ ᐃᑲᕐᕋᓂᒃ ᐱᖓᓱᓂᒃ. ᐃᕐᖐᓐᓈᖅᑕᐅᑎᒃᑯᑦ ᑎᑎᕋᕐᕕᒋᔪᖅᓇᑕᓯ ᐅᕗᖓ: go-mcts-go-sctm@dfo-mpo.gc.ca ᐅᖄᓚᕕᒋᓗᒋᓪᓘᓐᓃᑦ ᐅᕗᖓ: 1-418-648-5437 ᑐᑭᓯᒋᐊᒃᑲᓐᓂᕈᒪᒍᕕᑦ.
caption_cleaned: ᐃᖃᓗᒻᒥᐅᓄᑦ! ᐃᑲᔪᕈᒪᒐᔭᖅᑭᑦ ᐅᒥᐊᖅᑐᖅᑐᓂᒃ ᐱᔪᖃᑳᓪᓚᑦᑐᓂᒃ ᐊᑦᑕᓇᖅᑐᒃᑯᑦ ᐊᒻᒪᓗ ᐊᐳᖅᓯᑦᑕᐃᓕᒪᑎᑦᑎᓂᕐᒥᒃ ᐅᒥᐊᕐᓂᒃ? ᐊᑎᓕᐅᖁᕙᑦᓯ ᑕᕆᐅᕐᔪᐊᓕᕆᔨᒃᑯᑦ ᑲᒪᔨᒃᓴᓕᕆᔨᖏᓐᓄᑦ ᖃᐅᔨᒃᑲᐃᓂᕐᒧᑦ ᐃᖏᕐᕋᔪᓕᕆᓂᕐᒧᓪᓗ (MCTS-ᖑᓂᕋᖅᑕᐅᔪᖅ) ᐆᑦᑐᕋᖅᑎᑕᐅᖃᑕᐅᓂᐊᕋᕕᑦ ᐃᖃᓗᓐᓂ ᓈᑦᑎᖑᔭᒥ ᑎᓯᐱᕆ , Services Canada-ᒃᑯᓐᓂ ᐊᖅᑯᑎᖓ ᒥᕝᕕᐅᓂᕋᖅᑕᐅᔪᖅ, -ᒨᖅᑲᑦ. ᐆᑦᑐᖅᑕᐅᓂᐊᖅᑐᑦ ᐃᑲᕐᕋᓂᒃ ᐱᖓᓱᓂᒃ. ᐃᕐᖐᓐᓈᖅᑕᐅᑎᒃᑯᑦ ᑎᑎᕋᕐᕕᒋᔪᖅᓇᑕᓯ ᐅᕗᖓ: go-mcts-go-sctm-mpo.gc.ca ᐅᖄᓚᕕᒋᓗᒋᓪᓘᓐᓃᑦ ᐅᕗᖓ: -418-648-5437 ᑐᑭᓯᒋᐊᒃᑲᓐᓂᕈᒪᒍᕕᑦ.

caption_original:
For the TENTH day of our 12 day holiday countdown ☃️…. We participated in TEN Canada's 150th Anniversary of Confederation Celebrations!

This year, we were proud to participate in 5 Pride Parades; 2 meetups with Canada C3; Canada Day 150; 105th Grey Cup Festival and attend the Canada150 rink!
